translated: Sabhanara, Chakshusha and Parameshthu.🔽The son of Sabhanara was the learned king Kalana.

original: kālānalasya dharmmajñaḥ sṛñjayo nāma vai sutaḥ // / / //🔽sṛñjayasyābhavat putro vīro rājā purañjayaḥ /
analyzed: kālānalasya dharmma jñaḥ sṛñjayaḥ nāma vai sutaḥ  sṛñjayasya abhavat putraḥ vīraḥ rājā purañjayaḥ
translated: The son of Kalana was the virtuous king Srinjaya.🔽The son of Srinjaya was the heroic king Puranjaya.

analyzed: purañjaya ātmajaḥ śrīmān rājā abhūt janamejayaḥ
translated: The son of Puranjaya was the illustrious king Janamejaya.

analyzed: mahāśālaḥ tu rājarṣiḥ janamejaya deha jaḥ
translated: The royal sage Mahabhisha was born of Janamejaya.

analyzed: deveṣu sa parijñātaḥ pratiṣṭhita yaśāḥ bhuvi
translated: He was known to the gods and his fame was established on earth.

analyzed: mahāmanāḥ nāma sutaḥ mahāśālasya dhārmmikaḥ
translated: The son of Mahabhisha was the virtuous Mahamana.

original: jajñe vīraḥ śūragaṇaiḥ pūjitaḥ sa mahāmanāḥ // / / //
analyzed: jajñe vīraḥ śūra gaṇaiḥ pūjitaḥ sa mahāmanāḥ
translated: The heroic Mahamana was born and was worshipped by the assemblies of heroes.

analyzed: mahāmanāḥ tu putrau dvau janayāmāsa sattamaḥ
translated: Mahamana had two sons, the best of men.

analyzed: uśīnaram ca dharmma jñam titikṣum ca mahā balam
translated: Ushinara, the righteous, and Titikshu of great strength.

analyzed: uśīnarasya patnyaḥ tu pañca rāja ṛṣi vaṃśa jāḥ
translated: Ushinara had five wives born in the royal dynasties.

original: mṛgā kṛmirnavā darvvā pañcamī ca dṛṣadvatī // / / //
analyzed: mṛgā kṛmiḥ navā darvvā pañcamī ca dṛṣadvatī
translated: Mriga, Krimi, Nava, Darvva, and the fifth was Drshadvati.

analyzed: uśīnarasya putrāḥ tu pañca tāsu kula udvahāḥ
translated: Ushinara had five sons born of them, who perpetuated the family.

original: tapasā caiva mahatā jātā vṛddhasya cātmajāḥ // / / //
analyzed: tapasā ca eva mahatā jātāḥ vṛddhasya ca ātmajāḥ
translated: And they were born to the old king through great austerities.

analyzed: nṛgāyān tu nṛgaḥ putraḥ kṛmyām kṛmiḥ ajāyata
translated: Of Mriga was born Nriga, of Krimi was born Krimi,

analyzed: navāyāḥ tu navaḥ putraḥ darvvāyāḥ suvrataḥ bhavat
translated: of Nava was born Nava, of Darvva was born Suvrata.

analyzed: dṛṣadvatyāḥ tu saṃjajñe śiviḥ auśīnaraḥ nṛpaḥ
translated: And of Drshadvati was born king Shivi, the son of Ushinara.

original: śivestu śivayaḥ khyātāḥ yaudheyāstu mṛgasya ha // / / //
analyzed: śiveḥ tu śivayaḥ khyātāḥ yaudheyāḥ tu mṛgasya ha
translated: The Shivis are known as the sons of Shivi, and the Yaudheyas are the sons of Mriga.

analyzed: navasya kṛmeḥ tu kṛmilā purī
translated: The kingdom of Nava belongs to Nava, and the city of Krimi belongs to Krimi.

analyzed: suvratasya tathā ambaṣṭhāḥ śivi putrān nibodhata
translated: And Ambashtha belongs to Suvrata. Know the sons of Shivi.

analyzed: śiveḥ tu śivayaḥ putrāḥ catvāraḥ loka viśrutāḥ
translated: Shivi had four sons, famous in the world.

analyzed: vṛṣadarbhaḥ suvīraḥ ca kaikeyaḥ madrakaḥ tathā
translated: Vrishadarbha, Suvira, Kaikeya, and Madra.

analyzed: teṣām janapadāḥ sphītāḥ kaikeyāḥ madrakāḥ tathā
translated: Their prosperous countries are Kaikeya and Madra.

analyzed: vṛṣa darbhāḥ su vīrāḥ ca titikṣoḥ śṛṇuta prajāḥ
translated: The Vrishanbarhas and the Suviras, the descendants of Titiksha, listen to the names of the kings of the east.

original: taitikṣavo bhavadrājā pūrvasyāṃ diśi pārthivāḥ /🔽uṣadratho mahāsatvaḥ pheṇastasya suto 'bhavat // / / //
analyzed: taitikṣavaḥ bhavat rājā pūrvasyām diśi pārthivāḥ  uṣadrathaḥ mahā satvaḥ pheṇaḥ tasya sutaḥ bhavat
translated: The kings of the east were the descendants of Titiksha.🔽Ushadratha, of great strength, was the king of the east. His son was Phena.

original: pheṇātta sutapā jajñe sutaḥ sutapaso valiḥ /
analyzed: sutapāḥ jajñe sutaḥ sutapasaḥ valiḥ
translated: From Phena was born Sutashatha. His son was Vali.

analyzed: jātaḥ mānuṣa yaunau sa nṛpatiḥ kāñcana iṣudhiḥ
translated: He was born in the human race as a king with golden armour.

original: mahāyogī sa tu balirbabhūva nṛpatiḥ purā /
analyzed: mahā yogī sa tu baliḥ babhūva nṛpatiḥ purā
translated: In ancient times, Vali became a great yogi king.

original: putrānutpādayāmāsa pañca vaṃśakarān bhuvi // / / //🔽aṅgaḥ prathamato jajñe vaṅgaḥ suhmastathaiva ca /
analyzed: putrān utpādayāmāsa pañca vaṃśa karān bhuvi  aṅgaḥ prathamatas jajñe vaṅgaḥ suhmaḥ tathā eva ca
translated: He begot five sons who became founders of dynasties on earth.

original: puṇḍraḥ kaliṅgaśca tathā bāleyaṃ kṣatramucyate // / / //🔽bāleyā brāhmaṇāścaiva tasya vaṃśakarā bhuvi /
analyzed: puṇḍraḥ kaliṅgaḥ ca tathā bāleyam kṣatram ucyate  bāleyāḥ brāhmaṇāḥ ca eva tasya vaṃśa karāḥ bhuvi
translated: Anga was born first, then Vanga, Suhma, Pundra, and Kalinga. This is said to be the Kshatriya race of Bali.🔽The Brahmins of Bali's race became founders of dynasties on earth.

original: balestu brahmaṇā datto varaḥ prītena dhīmatā // / / //
analyzed: baleḥ tu brahmaṇā dattaḥ varaḥ prītena dhīmatā
translated: The wise and pleased Brahma granted a boon to Bali.

analyzed: mahā yogi tvam āyuḥ ca kalpasya parimāṇataḥ
translated: The boon was of great yoga, a lifespan equal to a kalpa,

analyzed: saṃgrāme ca api ajeya tvam dharmme ca eva pradhāna tā
translated: invincibility in battle, preeminence in dharma,

analyzed: trailokya darśanam ca api prādhānyam prasave tathā
translated: sight of the three worlds, and preeminence in progeny.

analyzed: bale ca apratima tvam vai dharmma tattva abhidarśanam
translated: And the truth of Dharma was revealed to him.

original: caturo niyatān varṇān tvañca sthāpayiteti ha // / / //
analyzed: caturaḥ niyatān varṇān tvañca sthāpayitā iti ha
translated: And you were asked to establish the four fixed castes.

original: ityukte vibhunā rājā baliḥ śāntiṃ parāṃ yayau /
analyzed: iti ukte vibhunā rājā baliḥ śāntim parām yayau
translated: When this was said by the Lord, King Bali attained supreme peace.

analyzed: baliḥ tān abhiṣicya iha pañca putrān akalmaṣān
translated: Having consecrated his five sinless sons here,

analyzed: kṛtārthaḥ yoga yukta ātmā yogam āśritya sa prabhuḥ
translated: the lord, his mind engaged in yoga, attained his own abode.

analyzed: adhṛṣyaḥ sarvva bhūtānām kāla apekṣī caran ṛṣiḥ
translated: The sage, unassailable by all beings, wandered, awaiting the time.

analyzed: kālena mahatā dhīraḥ svam ca sthānam upāgamat
translated: After a long time, the patient one returned to his own place.

original: teṣāṃ janapadāḥ pañca aṅgā vaṅgā sasuhmakā // / / //
analyzed: teṣām janapadāḥ pañca aṅgāḥ vaṅgā sa suhmakā
translated: Their five countries were Anga, Vanga, Suhma,

analyzed: kaliṅgāḥ puṇḍrakāḥ ca eva tvaṅgasya śṛṇuta prajāḥ
translated: Kalinga, and Pundra. Listen to the descendants of Anga.

analyzed: aṅga putraḥ mahān āsīt rāja indraḥ dadhivāhanaḥ
translated: Anga's son was the great king Dadhivana.

analyzed: dadhivāhana putraḥ tu rājā divirathaḥ bhavat
translated: Dadhivana's son was King Diviratha.

original: vidvān dharmmaratho nāma tasya citrarathaḥ sutaḥ // / / //
analyzed: vidvān dharmmarathaḥ nāma tasya citrarathaḥ sutaḥ
translated: His son was the learned Dharmaratha, whose son was Chitraratha.

analyzed: tena dharmmarathena atha tadā viṣṇupade girau
translated: Then, on Mount Vishnupada, the great soul,

original: yajatā saha śakreṇa somaḥ pīto mahātmanā // / / //
analyzed: yajatā saha śakreṇa somaḥ pītaḥ mahātmanā
translated: together with Shakra, offered a sacrifice and drank soma.

analyzed: atha citrarathasya api putraḥ daśarathaḥ bhavat
translated: Then Chitraratha had a son named Dasharatha.

original: lomapāda iti khyāto yasya śāntā sutābhavat // / / //
analyzed: lomapādaḥ iti khyātaḥ yasya śāntā sutā bhavat
translated: He became known as Lomapada, and he had a daughter named Shanta.

analyzed: tasya dāśarathiḥ vīraḥ caturaṅgaḥ mahā yaśāḥ
translated: His son was the heroic and greatly illustrious Dasharatha, who had four sons.

original: ṛṣvaśṛṅgaprasādena jajñe kulavivarddhanaḥ // / / //🔽caturaṅgasya putrastu pṛthulākṣa iti śrutaḥ /
analyzed: ṛṣvaśṛṅga prasādena jajñe kula vivarddhanaḥ  caturaṅgasya putraḥ tu pṛthulākṣaḥ iti śrutaḥ
translated: By the grace of Rishvasringa, he was born to increase the family.🔽The son of Dasharatha was known as Prithulaksha.

analyzed: pṛthulākṣa sutaḥ rājā campaḥ nāma mahā yaśāḥ
translated: His son was the great king Champa.

original: campasya tu purī campā yā mālinyabhavatpurā /
analyzed: campasya tu purī campā yā mālinī abhavat purā
translated: The city of Champa was formerly the city of Malini.

original: pūrṇabhadraprasādena haryyakṣosya suto 'bhavat // / / //🔽tato vaibhāṇḍakistasya vāraṇaṃ śatruvāraṇam /
analyzed: pūrṇabhadra prasādena haryyakṣaḥ usya sutaḥ bhavat  tatas vaibhāṇḍakiḥ tasya vāraṇam śatru vāraṇam
translated: By the grace of Purnabhadra, he had a son named Haryyaka.

original: bhuvyavatārayāmāsa mantrairvāhanamuttamam // / / // 🔽haryyakṣasya tu dāyādo rājā bhadrarathaḥ smṛtaḥ /
analyzed: bhuvi avatārayāmāsa mantraiḥ vāhanam uttamam  haryyakṣasya tu dāyādaḥ rājā bhadrarathaḥ smṛtaḥ
translated: Then Vibhandaka brought down on earth by mantras the excellent vehicle, the elephant that could destroy enemies.🔽The son of Haryyaka was known as King Bhadratha.🔽The son of Bhadratha was the king Brihatkarman.

original: putro bhadrarathasyāsīt vṛhatkarmmā prajeśvaraḥ // / / //🔽vṛhadarbhaḥ sutastasya yasmāt yajñe vṛhanmanāḥ /
analyzed: putraḥ bhadrarathasya āsīt vṛhatkarmmā prajeśvaraḥ  vṛhadarbhaḥ sutaḥ tasya yasmāt yajñe vṛhanmanāḥ
translated: His son was Brihaddarbha, from whom Brihadbhanu was born.

analyzed: vṛhanmanāḥ tu rāja indraḥ janayāmāsa vai sutam
translated: The king Brihadbhanu begot a son.

original: nāmnā jayadrathaṃ vīraṃ yasmāddṛḍharatho nṛpaḥ /🔽āsīt dṛḍharathasyāpi viśvajit kulanandanaḥ // / / //
analyzed: nāmnā jayadratham vīram yasmāt dṛḍharathaḥ nṛpaḥ  āsīt dṛḍharathasya api viśvajit kula nandanaḥ
translated: The king was known as Jayadratha, and from him was born the heroic king Dridharatha.🔽Dridharatha's son was Vishvajit, the delighter of his family.

analyzed: dāyādaḥ tasya karṇaḥ tu vikarṇaḥ tasya ca ātmajaḥ
translated: Karna was his heir, and Vikarna was Karna's son.

analyzed: tasya putra śatantu āsīt aṅgānām kula vardhanam
translated: He had a hundred sons, who extended the Anga dynasty.

analyzed: vṛhadarbha sutaḥ yaḥ tu rājā nāmnā vṛhanmanāḥ
translated: The son of Vrihadarva was the king named Vrihanmana.

analyzed: tasya patnī dvayam ca āsīt vainateya sute śubhe
translated: He had two wives, both of whom were the daughters of Vinata.

original: yaśodevī ca satyā ca tābhyāṃ vaṃśastu vidyate /
analyzed: yaśodevī ca satyā ca tābhyām vaṃśaḥ tu vidyate
translated: They were Yashodevi and Satya, and from them the dynasty is known.

analyzed: jayadrathaḥ tu rāja indraḥ yaśodevyām vyajāyata
translated: The king of kings, Jayadratha, was born from Yashodevi.

analyzed: satyāyām vijayaḥ nāma brahma kṣatra uttaraḥ smṛtaḥ
translated: From Satya was born Vijaya, known as the foremost of Brahmanas and Kshatriyas.

analyzed: vijayasya dhṛtiḥ putraḥ tasya putraḥ dhṛtavrataḥ
translated: Vijaya's son was Dhriti, and his son was Dhritavrata.

analyzed: dhṛtavratasya putraḥ tu satyakarmmā mahā yaśāḥ
translated: Dhritavrata's son was the greatly famous Satyakarma.

original: tasya putrastvadhirathaḥ suta ityaparābhidhaḥ // / / //🔽yaḥ karṇaṃ pratijagrāha tena karṇastu sūtajaḥ /
analyzed: tasya putraḥ tu adhirathaḥ sutaḥ iti apara abhidhaḥ  yaḥ karṇam pratijagrāha tena karṇaḥ tu sūtajaḥ
translated: His son was Adhiratha, also known as Suta.🔽He adopted Karna, and thus Karna became the son of a charioteer.

analyzed: karṇasya vṛṣasenaḥ tu pṛthusenaḥ tad ātmajaḥ
translated: Karna's son was Vrishasena, and his son was Prithushena.

analyzed: pṛthusena anvaye vīraḥ vīrasenaḥ bhaviṣyati
translated: In the lineage of Prithu, there will be a hero named Virasena.

analyzed: gauḍa brāhmaṇa kanyām yaḥ somaṭām udvahiṣyati
translated: He will marry Soma, the daughter of a Brahmin from Gauda.

analyzed: tad anvavāya janmānaḥ rājānaḥ mita pauruṣāḥ
translated: The kings born in his lineage will have unlimited valor.

analyzed: sapta dvīpa patīn vīrāḥ kariṣyanti vaśa anugān
translated: They will bring under their control the kings of the seven islands.

analyzed: tad vaṃśe sāmantasenaḥ bhūtvā pālayitā valī
translated: In his lineage, there will be a king named Samantasena, who will rule the earth.

analyzed: ā vindhyāt ā setu bandhāt haritrīm sāgarāmbarām
translated: From the Vindhya mountains to the ocean, he will be the protector.

analyzed: siṃhagiriḥ uvāca
translated: Siṃhagiri said:

analyzed: tasmāt hemantasenaḥ bhūt rājan tava pitāmahaḥ
translated: From him, O king, your grandfather was Hemaṃtasena,

analyzed: dhāma dhāmnām mahimnām ca dviṣat bala hutāśanaḥ
translated: the fire that consumed the strength and pride of enemies.

analyzed: tasmāt vijayasenaḥ bhūt ca uḍagaṅga sakhaḥ nṛpaḥ
translated: From him was born the king Vijayasena, the friend of the Chola and Gaṅga kings,

analyzed: yaḥ jayat pṛthivīm kṛtsnām catur sāgara mekhalām
translated: who conquered the entire earth girdled by the four oceans.

analyzed: tasya putraḥ si vallāla sārvvabhauma mahīkṣitaḥ
translated: O VALLĀLA, you are his son, the lord of the earth of all the lords of the earth,

analyzed: pratyarthi pṛthivīpālāḥ yasya te śaraṇam gatāḥ
translated: to whom the kings of the earth who are your enemies have gone for refuge.

analyzed: brahma kṣatrasya yaḥ yoniḥ vaṃśaḥ kṣatriya pūrvvajaḥ
translated: The lineage of the Brahmins and Kṣatriyas, in which the Kṣatriyas are the elders,

analyzed: sena vaṃśaḥ tatas jātaḥ pāṇḍava
translated: is the Sena lineage, in which you, O Pāṇḍava, were born.

original: dveṣṭi yaḥ pāṇḍavaṃ mūḍho durbuddhiśca vinindati /
analyzed: dveṣṭi yaḥ pāṇḍavam mūḍhaḥ durbuddhiḥ ca vinindati
translated: He who hates the Pandavas, O fool, and he who censures them with a wicked mind,

original: sa viṣṭhāyāṃ kṛmirbhūtvā pacyeta narake ciram // / / //
analyzed: sa viṣṭhāyām kṛmiḥ bhūtvā pacyeta narake ciram
translated: He shall be born as a worm in excrement and shall be cooked in hell for a long time.

analyzed: sa vallabha ānanda candraḥ candramā ayuta vallabhaḥ
translated: He is the moon of the joy of the beloved, the beloved of ten thousand moons.

original: tasyedānīṃ mahārāja kāryyaṃ bhavati śāsanam // / / //🔽tasyāsti kanyakāratnaṃ rūpeṇānupamaṃ bhuvi /
analyzed: tasya idānīm mahā rāja kāryyam bhavati śāsanam  tasya asti kanyakā ratnam rūpeṇa anupamam bhuvi
translated: Now, O great king, it is his command that should be carried out.🔽He has a jewel of a daughter, unmatched in beauty on earth.

analyzed: suprabhām iva nābhāgaḥ tām kanyām hara paurava
translated: O Nabhaga of the Puru race, take that daughter, as if she were the light of the rising sun.

original: uccandre sā yāti vālā gaurīṃ snātuṃ yadā yadā /
analyzed: uccandre sā yāti vālā gaurīm snātum yadā yadā
translated: When the moon rises, the young woman goes to the Ganges to bathe,

analyzed: tadā tadā tvarayati draṣṭum tām aruṇaḥ ruṇam
translated: then the rosy dawn hastens to see her.

analyzed: daṇḍa dvaya avaśeṣāyām rajanyām aruṇa udayam
translated: When the night has two watches left and the dawn breaks,

analyzed: vilokya ghariyāreṣu viśvasanti na naigamāḥ
translated: the merchants do not trust the lions.

original: iti vallālacarite vyāsapurāṇe puruvaṃśakīrttanaṃ nāma dvādaśo 'dhyāyaḥ /
analyzed: iti vallālacarite vyāsapurāṇe puruvaṃśakīrttanam nāma dvādaśaḥ dhyāyaḥ
translated: Thus ends the twelfth chapter in the Vamana Purana, composed by the great sage Vamana, the son of Varatantu.

analyzed: atha trayodaśaḥ dhyāyaḥ
translated: Now begins the thirteenth chapter.

analyzed: vyāsaḥ uvāca
translated: Vyasa said:

original: vedaḥ smṛtiḥ sadācāraḥ svasya ca priyamātmanaḥ /
analyzed: vedaḥ smṛtiḥ sat ācāraḥ svasya ca priyam ātmanaḥ
translated: The Veda, the Smriti, the conduct of the virtuous, and one's own inclination,

analyzed: samyak saṃkalpa jaḥ kāmaḥ dharmma mūlam idam smṛtam
translated: and the desire born of right resolution - this is declared to be the root of Dharma.

analyzed: adhyāpanam ca adhyayanam yajanam yājanam tathā
translated: Teaching, studying, sacrificing for oneself, sacrificing for others,

original: dānaṃ pratigrahaṃ karmma brāhmaṇānāmudāhṛtam // / / //🔽śrūtismṛtī ca viprāṇāṃ cakṣuṣī devanirmmite /
analyzed: dānam pratigraham karmma brāhmaṇānām udāhṛtam  śrūti smṛtī ca viprāṇām cakṣuṣī deva nirmmite
translated: giving and accepting gifts are declared to be the duties of Brahmins.🔽The Vedas and the Smritis are the eyes of Brahmins, created by the gods.

analyzed: kāṇaḥ tatra ekayā hīnaḥ dvābhyām andhaḥ prakīrttitaḥ
translated: One is blind in one eye if deficient in one, and blind in both eyes if deficient in both.

analyzed: vaivāhike ignau kurvvīta gṛhya karmma yathāvidhi
translated: One should perform the domestic rites in the marriage fire according to the rules,

analyzed: pañcayajña vidhānam ca paktim ca anvahikīm gṛhī
translated: and the householder should perform the five sacrifices and the daily cooking.

analyzed: adhyāpanam brahmayajñaḥ pitṛ yajñaḥ tu tarpaṇam
translated: Teaching is the sacrifice to Brahman, offering water libations is the sacrifice to the ancestors,

original: homo daivo balibhoto nṛyajño 'tithipūjanam // / / //🔽devatātithibhṛtyānāṃ pitḥṇāmātmanaśca yaḥ /
analyzed: homaḥ daivaḥ tithi pūjanam  devatā atithi bhṛtyānām pitḥṇām ātmanaḥ ca yaḥ
translated: the oblation is the divine sacrifice, and the offering of food is the sacrifice to humans.🔽One who does not offer to the five - gods, guests, servants, ancestors and oneself -

analyzed: na nirvvapati pañcānām ucchvasan na sa jīvati
translated: does not really live, though breathing.

analyzed: eka rātram vasan vipraḥ kṣatriyaḥ ca atithiḥ smṛtaḥ
translated: A Brahmin or a Kshatriya staying for one night is considered a guest.

analyzed: anityā hi sthitiḥ ryasmāt tasmāt atithiḥ ucyate
translated: Since his stay is uncertain, he is called a guest.

analyzed: vaiśya śūdrau api prāptau kuṭumbe tithi dharmmiṇau
translated: Even a Vaishya or a Shudra who arrives in the household is entitled to guest-treatment.

analyzed: bhojayet saha bhṛtyaiḥ stāva ānṛśaṃsyam pradarśayan
translated: One should feed them with their servants, showing compassion.

analyzed: sva dāra nirataḥ nityam para dāra vivarjjitaḥ
translated: He should always be devoted to his own wife and avoid the wives of others.

analyzed: kṛta homaḥ tu bhuñjīta sāyaṃprātar udāra dhīḥ
translated: Having performed the Homa, the generous-minded one should eat in the morning and evening.

analyzed: sarvvatas pratigṛhṇīyāt avṛttyā karṣitaḥ dvijaḥ
translated: A twice-born man, if reduced by want of subsistence, may accept gifts from all;

original: na bhaveddoṣabhāk tena jvalanārkasamo hi saḥ // / / //
analyzed: na bhavet doṣa bhāj tena jvalana arka samaḥ hi saḥ
translated: he does not thereby incur sin, for he is like unto fire or the sun.

analyzed: bhūtānām rakṣaṇam dānam ijyā adhyayanam eva ca
translated: The protection of creatures, charity, sacrifice, and study,

analyzed: śiva arcanam kṣatriyāṇām tathā nārāyaṇa arccanam
translated: and the worship of Shiva and Narayana are the duties of Kshatriyas.

analyzed: nitya udyuktaḥ dasyu vadhe raṇe kuryyāt parākramam
translated: Always engaged in slaying robbers, he should show prowess in battle.

original: nāsya kṛtyatamaṃ kiñcit rājño dasyuvinigrahāt // / / //🔽cāṭabhāṭataskarebhyo mahāsāhasikādibhiḥ /
analyzed: na asya kṛtyatamam kiñcid rājñaḥ dasyu vinigrahāt  cāṭa bhāṭa taskarebhyaḥ mahāsāhasika ādibhiḥ
translated: For a king, there is no duty superior to the suppression of robbers.

analyzed: pīḍyamānāḥ prajāḥ rakṣet kāyasthaiḥ ca viśeṣataḥ
translated: He should protect the people afflicted by flatterers, servants, thieves, great adventurers, and so on, especially by scribes.

original: sammānadānasatkāraiḥ vaidikān vāsayet sadā /🔽rājanyo dharmmakṛtyañca kuryyādeva prayatnataḥ // / / //
analyzed: sammāna dāna satkāraiḥ vaidikān vāsayet sadā  rājanyaḥ dharmma kṛtyam ca kuryyāt eva prayatnataḥ
translated: He should always support the Vedic scholars with honor, gifts, and good treatment.🔽The Kshatriya should always carefully perform his religious duties.

analyzed: paṇḍitam nīti śāstra jñam nityam ca pratipālayet
translated: He should always support a learned man who is well-versed in the science of politics.

analyzed: niyojayet sabhā madhye nityam sadbhiḥ ca saṃyutaḥ
translated: He should always employ him in the assembly, being always united with the virtuous.

analyzed: saṃviśet tūryya ghoṣeṇa pratibudhyet tathā eva ca
translated: He should go to bed to the sound of musical instruments and rise in the same way.

analyzed: śāstrāṇi cintayet buddhyā sarvva karttavya tām tathā
translated: He should reflect on the scriptures with his intellect and on all that needs to be done.

original: dṛṣṭvā jyotirvvido vaidyān dadyāt gāṃ kāñcanaṃ mahīm /
analyzed: dṛṣṭvā jyotiḥ vvidaḥ vaidyān dadyāt gām kāñcanam mahīm
translated: Having seen astrologers and physicians, he should give a cow, gold, and land.

original: niveśikāni ca tathā śrotriyāṇāṃ gṛhāni ca // / / //🔽ya eva dharmmo nṛpateḥ svarāṣṭrapratipālane /
analyzed: niveśikāni ca tathā śrotriyāṇām gṛhāni ca  yaḥ eva dharmmaḥ nṛpateḥ sva rāṣṭra pratipālane
translated: And he should build houses for the learned and for the Brahmins.🔽The very same duties that a king has in protecting his own kingdom,

analyzed: tam eva kṛtsnam āpnoti para rāṣṭram vaśam nayan
translated: he obtains in their entirety when bringing another kingdom under his sway.

analyzed: deva brāhmaṇa bhaktaḥ ca pitṛ kāryya parāyaṇaḥ
translated: Devoted to gods and Brahmins, intent on ancestral rites,

analyzed: sva bhāryyā nirataḥ nityam ṣaḍbhāga arhaḥ sadā nṛpaḥ
translated: always devoted to his own wife, the king deserves a sixth part (of the people's income).

analyzed: eka aṃśena balam dhāryyam dānam aṃśa dvayena ca
translated: One part should be used to maintain the army, two parts for gifts,

analyzed: eka aṃśena prakṛtayaḥ eka aṃśena adhikāriṇaḥ
translated: one part for the common people, and one part for the officials.

analyzed: eka aṃśena ātma bhogaḥ ca kuṭumba ādi prapālanam
translated: One part for his own enjoyment and the maintenance of his family and so on.

original: āyasyaivaṃ ṣaḍavibhāgai rvyayaṃ kuryyānmahīpatiḥ // / / //🔽sandhyāmupāsya kurute gītaṃ vādyaṃ manoharam /
analyzed: āyasya evam ṣaṣ avibhāgaiḥ vyayam kuryyāt mahīpatiḥ  sandhyām upāsya kurute gītam vādyam manoharam
translated: The king should make his expenditure in six parts like this from his income.🔽Having performed the evening worship, he should enjoy music and instruments that delight the mind.

analyzed: nṛtya gītaiḥ ca jagdhīm vā strībhiḥ niśi sukha āvahām
translated: He should spend the night happily with women through dancing and singing.

analyzed: gorakṣām kṛṣi vāṇijyam kuryyāt vaiśyaḥ yathāvidhi
translated: A Vaishya should engage in cow protection, agriculture and trade according to the rules.

analyzed: dānam deyam yathāśaktyā brāhmaṇānām ca bhojanam
translated: Charity should be given according to one's ability and Brahmins should be fed.

analyzed: dambha moha vinirmmuktaḥ tathā vāc anasūyakaḥ
translated: Free from arrogance and delusion, and likewise, not backbiting with speech.

analyzed: sva dāra nirataḥ dāntaḥ para dāra vivarjjitaḥ
translated: Devoted to one's own wife, self-controlled, and avoiding the wives of others.

analyzed: dhanaiḥ viprān bhojayitvā yajña kāle tu yājakān
translated: Having fed the Brahmins with wealth, and the priests at the time of sacrifice.

analyzed: a prabhu tvam ca vartteta dharmmeṣu ā deha pātanāt
translated: And there should be no lordship in matters of Dharma until the fall of the body.

analyzed: yajña adhyayana dānāni kuryyāt nityam atandritaḥ
translated: One should perform sacrifices, study, and give charity, always being diligent.

analyzed: pitṛ kāryya paraḥ ca eva viṣṇu śiva arccanā paraḥ
translated: And devoted to the rites for the ancestors, and devoted to the worship of Vishnu and Shiva.

original: varṇatrayasya śuśrūṣāṃ kuryyācchūdraḥ prayatnataḥ /🔽dāsavadbrāhmaṇānāṃ ca viśeṣeṇa samācaret // / / //
analyzed: varṇa trayasya śuśrūṣām kuryyāt śūdraḥ prayatnataḥ  dāsa vat brāhmaṇānām ca viśeṣeṇa samācaret
translated: A Shudra should serve the three higher castes with effort.🔽He should especially behave like a servant towards Brahmins.

analyzed: a yācita pradātā syāt kṛṣim vṛtti artham āśrayet
translated: He should give without being asked, and resort to agriculture for the sake of livelihood.

analyzed: śuddhā tu vṛttiḥ tasya eva kāru cāraṇa karmma ca
translated: But his livelihood should be pure, and he should engage in the work of artisans.

analyzed: pākayajña vidhānena yajet devān atandritaḥ
translated: He should diligently worship the gods according to the rules of the Pakayajna (domestic rituals).

original: tasya tu dvijaśuśrūṣā paro dharmmaḥ prakīrttitaḥ // / / //
analyzed: tasya tu dvija śuśrūṣā paraḥ dharmmaḥ prakīrttitaḥ
translated: But for him, serving the twice-born is declared to be the highest duty.

analyzed: dhāraṇam jīrṇa vastrasya viprasya ucchiṣṭa bhojanam
translated: Wearing old clothes, eating the food left over by a Brahmin,

analyzed: sva dāreṣu ratiḥ ca eva para dāra vivarjanam
translated: Delighting in one's own wife and avoiding the wife of another,

original: lavaṇaṃ madhutailaṃ ca dadhi takraṃ ghṛtaṃ payaḥ /
analyzed: lavaṇam madhu tailam ca dadhi takram ghṛtam payaḥ
translated: Salt, honey, oil, curd, buttermilk, ghee, and milk,

analyzed: na duṣyet śūdra jātīnām kuryyāt sarvvasya vikrayam
translated: Are not defiled for selling to all Shudra castes.

analyzed: kriyā bhedaiḥ tu sarvveṣām bhṛti vṛttiḥ aninditā
translated: But for all, the occupation of wages is blameless through the divisions of rites.

analyzed: sīra bhedaiḥ kṛṣiḥ proktā manu ādyaiḥ brāhmaṇa ādiṣu
translated: Agriculture is said to be through the divisions of plows by Manu and others for Brahmins and others.

analyzed: brāhmaṇaiḥ ṣoḍaśa gabam catur ūnam tathā aparaiḥ
translated: For Brahmins, a plow with sixteen goads, for others with four less,

original: dvigavaṃ vāntyajaiḥ sīraṃ dṛṣṭvā bhūmārddavaṃ tathā // / / //
analyzed: dvigavam vānti ajaiḥ sīram dṛṣṭvā bhū mārddavam tathā
translated: For the lowest castes, a plow with two goads, and plowing the land is seen thus.

analyzed: bhūmim bhitvā oṣadhim chitvā hatvā kīṭa pipīlikām
translated: Having plowed the land, cut the herbs, and killed insects and ants,

original: punanti khalu yajñena karṣakā devapūjanāt // / / //🔽vaidikaiḥ karmmabhiḥ puṇyairniṣekādirdvijanmanām /
analyzed: punanti khalu yajñena karṣakāḥ deva pūjanāt  vaidikaiḥ karmmabhiḥ puṇyaiḥ niṣeka ādiḥ dvijanmanām
translated: Farmers are indeed purified by sacrifice through worship of the gods.🔽For twice-born people, the sacred rites beginning with impregnation should be performed by Vedic rites,

original: kāryyaḥ śarīrasaṃskāraḥ pāvanaḥ pretya ceha ca // / / //
analyzed: kāryaḥ śarīra saṃskāraḥ pāvanaḥ pretya ca iha ca
translated: The purification of the body is purifying for the next world and this world.

analyzed: garbhādhānam ṛtau puṃsaḥ savanam spandanāt purā
translated: Impregnation at the right time for a man, the rite of impregnation before the fetus moves,

original: turyye 'ṣṭame vā sīmanto janane jātakarmma ca // / / //
analyzed: turyye ṣṭame vā sīmantaḥ janane jātakarmma ca
translated: The Sīmanta ceremony is performed in the fourth or eighth month, and the Jātakarma (naming ceremony) at the birth.

analyzed: niṣkramaḥ tṛtīya māsi nāma vyuṣṭe śata ahani
translated: The Niṣkramaṇa (first taking out of the child) is performed in the third month, the Namakarman (naming) on the hundredth day,

analyzed: ṣaṣṭhe innaprāśanam cūḍā jani abde vā yathākulam
translated: The Annaprāśana (first feeding with rice) and Cūḍākarman (cutting the fontanelle) are performed in the sixth year, or in the birth year according to the family.
The Karṇavedha (piercing the ears), Vratādheṣaṇa (initiation into vows), Vedārambha (commencement of Vedic studies), Kriyāvidhi (ritual procedures),

analyzed: keśāntaḥ snānam udvāhaḥ vivāha agni parigrahaḥ
translated: Keśānta (tonsure), Snāna (bath), Udvāha (marriage), Vivaha (marriage), Agniparigraha (accepting the sacred fire),

analyzed: tretāgni saṃgrahaḥ ca iti saṃskārāḥ ṣoḍaśa smṛtāḥ
translated: and the collection of the three sacred fires - these are considered to be the sixteen sacraments.

original: navaitāḥ karṇavedhāntāḥ mantravarjjaṃ kriyā striyāḥ // / / //🔽vipro garbhāṣṭame varṣe kṣatra ekādaśe tathā /
analyzed: navā etāḥ karṇa vedha antāḥ mantra varjjam kriyā striyāḥ  vipraḥ garbha aṣṭame varṣe kṣatre ekādaśe tathā
translated: For women, these nine ending with Karṇavedha (ear piercing) are performed without mantras.🔽A Brahmin boy is entitled to the Vratopanaayana (investiture with the sacred cord) in the eighth year from conception, a Kshatriya in the eleventh,

analyzed: dvādaśe vaiśya jātiḥ tu vrata upanayam arhati
translated: and a Vaisya in the twelfth year.

analyzed: tasya prāpta vratasya ayam kālaḥ syāt viguṇa adhikaḥ
translated: For him who has attained the vow, this time should be double or more.

original: vedavratacyuto vrātyaḥ sa vrātyastomamarhati // / / //🔽brāhmo daivastathaivārṣaḥ prājāpatyastathāsuraḥ /
analyzed: veda vrata cyutaḥ vrātyaḥ sa vrātyastomam arhati  brāhmaḥ daivaḥ tathā eva ārṣaḥ prājāpatyaḥ tathā āsuraḥ
translated: One who has fallen from the Vedic vow becomes a Vrātya, and he deserves the Vrātya-stoma (sacrifice).

analyzed: gāndharbbaḥ rākṣasaḥ ca eva paiśācaḥ ca aṣṭamaḥ dhamaḥ
translated: The eight forms of marriage are: Brāhma, Daiva, Ārṣa, Prājāpatya, Āsura, Gāndharva, Rākṣasa, and Paiśāca, the lowest.

original: ete dharmmāstu catvāraḥ pūrvvaṃ vipre prakīrttitāḥ /
analyzed: ete dharmmāḥ tu catvāraḥ pūrvvam vipre prakīrttitāḥ
translated: These four are declared to be the first for the Brahmin.

analyzed: gāndharbbaḥ rākṣasaḥ ca eva kṣatriyasya praśasyate
translated: The Gandharva and Rakshasa forms are commended for a Kshatriya.

analyzed: a prārthitaḥ prayatnena brāhmaḥ tu parikīrttitaḥ
translated: The Brahma form is declared to be when a girl is not solicited, but is given with great effort.

analyzed: prārthita artha pradānena prājāpatyaḥ prakīrttitaḥ
translated: The Prajapatya form is declared to be when a girl is given after soliciting for her hand.

analyzed: āsuraḥ draviṇā dānāt gāndharbbaḥ samayāt mithas
translated: The Asura form is by the giving of wealth, the Gandharva form is by mutual consent,

analyzed: rākṣasaḥ yuddha haraṇāt paiśācaḥ kanyakā chalāt
translated: The Rakshasa form is by carrying away by force, and the Paisacha form is by deception of the girl.

original: tisrastu bhāryyāḥ kṣatrasya bhāryaikā brāhmaṇasya tu /
analyzed: tisraḥ tu bhāryyāḥ kṣatrasya bhāryā ekā brāhmaṇasya tu
translated: Three wives are sanctioned for a Kshatriya, one for a Brahmana,

original: ekaiva bhāryyā vaiśyasya śūdrasya ca vidhīyate // / / //
analyzed: ekā eva bhāryyā vaiśyasya śūdrasya ca vidhīyate
translated: And one wife is ordained for a Vaishya and a Shudra.

original: kṣatriyā vaiśyā śūdrā ca kṣatriyasya prakīrttitā /
analyzed: kṣatriyā vaiśyā śūdrā ca kṣatriyasya prakīrttitā
translated: A Kshatriya girl, a Vaishya girl, and a Shudra girl are sanctioned for a Kshatriya.

original: ekaiva bhāryyā viprasya brāhmaṇī tu vidhīyate // / / //
analyzed: ekā eva bhāryyā viprasya brāhmaṇī tu vidhīyate
translated: Only one wife, a Brahmani, is ordained for a Brahmana.

original: vaiśyaiva bhāryyā vaiśyasya śūdrā śūdrasya kīrttitā /
analyzed: vaiśyā eva bhāryyā vaiśyasya śūdrā śūdrasya kīrttitā
translated: A Vaishya girl is sanctioned for a Vaishya, and a Shudra girl for a Shudra.

analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ na udvahet kanyām asavarṇām kadācana
translated: A Brahmana should never marry a girl of an inferior caste.

analyzed: brāhmaṇāt vaiśya kanyāyām ambaṣṭhaḥ yaḥ vyajāyata
translated: The Ambashtha who is born from a Brahmana and a Vaishya girl,

original: sa tu śūdratvamāpanno vivahenna tato viśām // / / //
analyzed: sa tu śūdra tvam āpannaḥ vivahet na tatas viśām
translated: Has become a Shudra and should not marry a girl of a higher caste.

analyzed: śūdrā bhāryyasya pātityam rājanyasya yat ucyate
translated: The degradation that is declared for a Kshatriya who marries a Shudra woman,

original: naitanmama mataṃ jñeyaṃ sā tenonnīyate yataḥ // / / //
analyzed: na etat mama matam jñeyam sā tena unnīyate yatas
translated: That should not be regarded as my opinion, since she is raised up by him.

analyzed: patet vipraḥ ca vaiśyaḥ ca śūdrām kanyām udāvahan
translated: A Brahmana and a Vaishya would fall by marrying a Shudra maiden.

analyzed: pātityam na asti kṣatrasya śadrū dāra upasaṃgrahāt
translated: There is no degradation for a Kshatriya by taking a Shudra wife, because of the inclusion of Shudras.

analyzed: vipra kanyā vivāhaḥ pi kṛtaḥ rājarṣibhiḥ purā
translated: The marriage of a Brahmana maiden was also performed by royal sages in ancient times.

original: tejīyasāṃ na doṣāya vahneḥ sarvvabhujo yathā // / / //
analyzed: tejīyasām na doṣāya vahneḥ sarvva bhujaḥ yathā
translated: It does not lead to sin for the powerful, just as it does not for fire which consumes everything.

analyzed: rājā naḥ na avamantavyaḥ nṛ buddhyā manuḥ abravīt
translated: Manu has said that a king should not be despised with the idea that he is a man.

analyzed: mahatī devatā hi eṣā nara rūpeṇa tiṣṭhati
translated: For he is a great deity abiding in human form.

analyzed: anuṣṭhitam tu yat devaiḥ munibhiḥ yat anuṣṭhitam
translated: What has been performed by the gods and what has been performed by the sages,

analyzed: na anuṣṭheyam manuṣyaiḥ tad uktam karmma samācaret
translated: That should not be performed by men. One should perform the rites as stated.

analyzed: ūḍhāyām hi savarṇāyām aviprām kāmam udvahet
translated: For when a wife of the same caste has been married, one may marry a Shudra woman out of desire.

analyzed: tasyām utpāditaḥ putraḥ na savarṇāt prahīyate
translated: A son begotten on her is not excluded from the same caste.

original: kṣatrājjātaḥ kṣatriyāyāṃ kṣatriyaḥ syāt na saṃśayaḥ /
analyzed: kṣatrāt jātaḥ kṣatriyāyām kṣatriyaḥ syāt na saṃśayaḥ
translated: One born from a Kshatriya on a Kshatriya woman would be a Kshatriya, there is no doubt.

original: vaiśyāyāṃ ca tathaiva syāt śadrāyāmapi caiva hi // / / //
analyzed: vaiśyāyām ca tathā eva syāt śadrāyām api ca eva hi
translated: And so he would be from a Vaishya woman, and also from a Shudra woman.

analyzed: yāvat na vindate jāyām tāvat arddhaḥ bhavet pumān
translated: As long as a man does not get a wife, he is only half a man.

original: nārddhaṃ prajāyate sarvvaṃ prajāyete iti śrutiḥ // / / //
analyzed: na arddham prajāyate sarvvam prajāyete iti śrutiḥ
translated: The whole is not born without half. This is the Vedic statement.

analyzed: sa kāmāyāntu kanyāyām saṅgame na asti atikramaḥ
translated: But there is no transgression in the union with a willing maiden.

analyzed: kintu alaṃkṛtya satkṛtya saḥ eva enām samudvahet
translated: But he should marry her only after adorning and honoring her well.

analyzed: savarṇām udvahet bhāryyām prathamam dharmma siddhaye
translated: One should first marry a woman of the same caste for the sake of Dharma.

analyzed: tatas hi apratilomena yathākāmam vahet nṛpaḥ
translated: Then the king may marry as he pleases, without going against the rules.

original: viṣādyathāmṛtaṃ grāhyamamedhyāt kāñcanaṃ yathā /🔽nīcādyathottamā vidyā strīratnaṃ duṣkulāttathā // / / //
analyzed: viṣāt yathā amṛtam grāhyam amedhyāt kāñcanam yathā  nīcāt yathā uttamā vidyā strī ratnam duṣkulāt tathā
translated: Just as nectar should be taken even from poison, gold even from filth,🔽and just as the best knowledge is from the low, so is a jewel of a woman from a bad family.

analyzed: striyaḥ ratnāni atho vidyā dharmmaḥ śaucam subhāṣitam
translated: Women, jewels, knowledge, Dharma, purity, good sayings,

analyzed: vividhāni ca śilpāni samādeyāni sarvvatas
translated: and various arts should be accepted from everywhere.

original: yatra nāryyastu pūjyante ramante tatra devatāḥ /
analyzed: yatra nāryyaḥ tu pūjyante ramante tatra devatāḥ
translated: Where women are worshipped, there the gods rejoice.

analyzed: yatra etāḥ tu na pūjyante sarvvāḥ tatra aphalāḥ kriyāḥ
translated: Where they are not worshipped, all rites are fruitless there.

analyzed: prajana artham mahābhāgā pūjā arhāḥ gṛha dīptayaḥ
translated: For procreation, they are greatly fortunate, worthy of worship, and the light of the home.

original: striyaḥ śriyaśca geheṣu na viśeṣo 'sti kaścana // / / //
analyzed: striyaḥ śriyaḥ ca geheṣu na viśeṣaḥ sti kaścana
translated: There is no difference at all between women and Lakshmi in the houses.

original: utpādanamapatyasya jātasya paripālanam /🔽pratyahaṃ lokayātrāyāḥ pratyakṣaṃ strī nibandhanam // / / //
analyzed: utpādanam apatyasya jātasya paripālanam  pratyaham lokayātrāyāḥ pratyakṣam strī nibandhanam
translated: The begetting of children, the protection of those born,🔽The daily progress of the world is directly dependent on women.

analyzed: apatyam dārakarmmāṇi śuśraṣā ratiḥ uttamā
translated: Children, duties of the wife, service, supreme pleasure,

analyzed: dāra adhīnaḥ tathā svargaḥ pitḥṇām ātmanaḥ ca vai
translated: Heaven is dependent on the wife, as well as for the ancestors and oneself.

original: iti vallālacarite vyāsapurāṇe varṇadharmmādikīrttanaṃ nāma trayodaśo 'dhyāyaḥ /
analyzed: iti vallālacarite vyāsapurāṇe varṇadharmmādikīrttanam nāma trayodaśaḥ dhyāyaḥ
translated: Thus ends the thirteenth chapter in the Vyakarana-Purana, named Vallabha-Charitra, describing the duties of the social classes and others.

analyzed: atha caturdaśaḥ dhyāyaḥ
translated: Now, the fourteenth chapter.

analyzed: vyāsaḥ uvāca
translated: Vyasa said:

analyzed: śastā strī cāru sarvva aṅgī matta mātaṅga gāminī
translated: A praiseworthy woman has beautiful limbs, moves like an intoxicated elephant,

analyzed: guru ūru jaghanā yā ca kṛṣṇasāra mṛga īkṣaṇā
translated: Has heavy thighs and hips, and eyes like a black antelope.

analyzed: su nīla keśī tanu aṅgī viloma aṅgī manoharā
translated: She has very dark hair, a slender body, hair growing in the opposite direction, and is captivating.

original: samabhūmispṛśau pādau saṃhatau ca tathā stanau // / / //
analyzed: sama bhūmi spṛśau pādau saṃhatau ca tathā stanau

original: maṇḍape maṇḍale dānaṃ devān prācyārpayeddvije /🔽dravyasya nāma gṛhṇīyāt dadāni ca tathā vadet // / / //
analyzed: maṇḍape maṇḍale dānam devān prācyā arpayet dvije  dravyasya nāma gṛhṇīyāt dadāni ca tathā vadet
translated: In a pavilion or a circle, one should make gifts to gods and Brahmins.🔽One should mention the name of the substance and say I am giving.

original: toyaṃ dadyāttato haste dāne vidhirayaṃ smṛtaḥ /
analyzed: toyam dadyāt tatas haste dāne vidhiḥ ayam smṛtaḥ
translated: Then water should be given in the hand. This is the procedure remembered for making gifts.

analyzed: manasā pātram uddiśya jalam bhūmau vinikṣapet
translated: With the recipient in mind, one should pour water on the ground.

analyzed: vidyate sāgarasya antaḥ dānasya antaḥ na vidyate
translated: The end of the ocean exists, but the end of giving does not exist.

analyzed: yathānāma sagotrāya pravarāya āmukāya ca
translated: To such and such a person of such and such a name, of such and such a lineage, to the excellent one,

analyzed: veda vedāṅga yuktāya pātrāya su mahātmane
translated: To the great-souled recipient endowed with the Vedas and Vedangas,

analyzed: mātā pitroḥ ātmanaḥ ca puṇya yaśaḥ abhivṛddhaye
translated: For the increase of merit and fame of mother, father and oneself,

analyzed: sarvva pāpa upaśānti artham svarga artham bhukti muktaye
translated: For the sake of peace from all sins, for heaven, for enjoyment and liberation,

analyzed: yathānāma mahā dravyam viṣṇu rudra ādi daivatam
translated: To the great substance named such and such, with Vishnu, Shiva and other deities,

original: etattubhyaṃ sampradade prīyatāṃ me hariḥ śivaḥ // / / //
analyzed: etat tubhyam sampradade prīyatām me hariḥ śivaḥ
translated: I give this to you. May Hari and Shiva be pleased with me.

analyzed: etad dāna pratiṣṭhā artham suvarṇam dakṣiṇām dade
translated: For the establishment of this gift, I give gold as dakshina.

analyzed: anena dāna vākyena sarvva dānāni vai dadet
translated: With this statement of giving, one should give all gifts.

analyzed: suvarṇe dīyamāne tu rajatam dakṣiṇā iṣyate
translated: When gold is given, silver is considered the Dakshina.

analyzed: anyeṣām api dānānām suvarṇam dakṣiṇā smṛtā
translated: For other gifts also, gold is remembered as the Dakshina.

original: suvarṇaṃ rajataṃ tāmraṃ taṇḍulaṃ dhānyameva ca /
analyzed: suvarṇam rajatam tāmram taṇḍulam dhānyam eva ca
translated: Gold, silver, copper, rice, and grain -

analyzed: nitya śrāddham deva pūjā sarvvam etat adakṣiṇam
translated: all these are not Dakshina in daily Shraddha and worship of gods.

analyzed: rajatam dakṣiṇā pitrye dharmma kāma artha sādhanam
translated: Silver is the Dakshina in ancestral rites, accomplishing Dharma, desire, and wealth.

analyzed: suvarṇam rajatam tāmram maṇi muktā vasūni ca
translated: Gold, silver, copper, gems, pearls, and wealth -

analyzed: sarvvam etat mahā prājñe dadāti vasudhām dadat
translated: all this a man gives when he gives land, O you of great wisdom.

analyzed: pitṛḥ ca pitṛ loka sthān deva sthāne ca devatā
translated: The manes residing in the world of manes and the deities residing in the world of gods

analyzed: santarpayati śānta ātmā yaḥ dadāti vasundharām
translated: are satisfied by the man of tranquil soul who gives away land.

original: kharvvaṭaṃ kheṭakaṃ vāpi grāmaṃ vā śasyaśālinam // / / //
analyzed: kharvvaṭam kheṭakam vā api grāmam vā śasya śālinam
translated: A village full of corn, or a hamlet, or a field full of crops,

analyzed: nivarttana śatam vā api tad arddham vā gṛha ādikam
translated: or a hundred villages, or half that number, or a house,

analyzed: api āḍhā āvāpa mātram vā dattvā urvvīm phala bhāj bhavet
translated: or even a small piece of land, by giving which one becomes the enjoyer of the fruits of the earth.

analyzed: ikṣubhiḥ santatām bhūmim yava godhama śālinīm
translated: The land covered with sugarcane, barley, and rice,

analyzed: dadāti veda viduṣe sa na bhūyas abhijāyate
translated: he who gives to a knower of the Vedas is not born again.

analyzed: phāla kṛṣṭām mahīm dattvā sa vṛkṣām śasya śālinīm
translated: By giving a tilled piece of land along with trees and crops,

analyzed: yāvat sūryya karāla īkāḥ tāvat svarge mahīyate
translated: One is honored in heaven as long as the sun's rays shine.

analyzed: viprāya dadyāt ca guṇa anvitāya
translated: One should give to a virtuous brahmin,

analyzed: tapaḥ bhiyuktāya jita indriyāya
translated: Who is engaged in austerities and has conquered the senses.

analyzed: yāvat mahī tiṣṭhati sāgara antā
translated: As long as the earth with its oceans remains,

analyzed: tāvat phalam tasya bhavet anantam
translated: His fruits will be endless.

analyzed: yathā vījāni rohanti prakīrṇāni mahī tale
translated: Just as seeds grow when scattered on the ground,

analyzed: evam kāmāḥ prarohanti bhūmi dāna samārjitāḥ
translated: In the same way, desires grow when fulfilled by giving land.

analyzed: yathā apsu patitaḥ sadyas taila vinduḥ prasarpati
translated: Just as a drop of oil falls into the water and spreads,

original: evaṃ bhūmikṛtaṃ dānaṃ śasye śakṣye prarohati // / / //
analyzed: evam bhūmi kṛtam dānam śasye śakṣye prarohati
translated: In the same way, the gift of land grows in the field of merit.

analyzed: anna dāḥ sukhinaḥ nityam vastra daḥ ca eva rūpavān
translated: Those who give food are always happy, and the giver of clothes becomes handsome.

original: sa naraḥ sarvvado bhūpā yo dadāti vasundharām // / / //
analyzed: sa naraḥ sarvva daḥ bhūpāḥ yaḥ dadāti vasundharām
translated: That man who always gives land becomes a king.

analyzed: yathā gauḥ bharate vatsam kṣīram utsṛjya kṣīriṇī
translated: Just as a milch cow, abandoning her milk, nourishes her calf,

analyzed: evam dattāḥ mahīpālāḥ bhūmiḥ bharati bhūmi dam

analyzed: ādityaḥ varuṇaḥ viṣṇuḥ brahmā somaḥ hutāśanaḥ

analyzed: śūlapāṇiḥ ca bhagavān abhinandati bhūmi dam

analyzed: āsphoṭayanti pitaraḥ varṇayanti pitāmahāḥ

original: bhūmidātā kule jātaḥ sa nastrātā bhaviṣyati // / / //

analyzed: bahubhiḥ vasudhā dattā rājabhiḥ sagara ādibhiḥ

analyzed: bhūmim yaḥ pratigṛhṇāti yaḥ ca bhūmim prayacchati

analyzed: ubhau tau puṇya karmmāṇau niyatau svarga gāmiṇau

analyzed: dadyāt bhūmim nibandham vā kṛtvā lekhyam ca kārayet
translated: One should give land or mortgage it and have it recorded in writing,

analyzed: āgāmi bhadra nṛpati parijñānāya pārthivaḥ

analyzed: paṭe vā tāmra paṭṭe vā sva mudrā upari cihnitam

analyzed: abhilekhya ātmanaḥ vaṃśān ātmānañca mahīpatiḥ
translated: The king should record his lineage and himself.

analyzed: pratigraha pariccheda dāna āccheda upavarṇanam
translated: The description of accepting and giving land,

analyzed: sva hasta kāla sampannam śāsanam kārayet sthiram
translated: He should have a firm decree, with his own hand and the date.

analyzed: suvarṇa dānam go dānam bhūmi dānañca pārthivāḥ
translated: Kings, the gift of gold, the gift of cows, and the gift of land,

analyzed: etat prayacchamānaḥ tu sarvva pāpaiḥ pramucyate

analyzed: agnerapatyam prathamam suvarṇam
translated: Gold is the first offspring of fire,

analyzed: bhūḥ vaiṣṇavī sūrya sutāḥ ca gāvaḥ

analyzed: yaḥ kāñcanam gān ca mahīn ca dadyāt

analyzed: dattāḥ trayaḥ tena bhavanti lokāḥ

analyzed: sa sarvvam kulam uddhṛtya svarge loke mahīyate

analyzed: kṛtvā api pāpa karmmāṇi yaḥ dadyāt annam arthine
translated: Even having committed sinful deeds, he who would give food to a supplicant,

analyzed: brāhmaṇāya viśeṣeṇa sa pāpena na lipyate

analyzed: tri sapta kulam uddhṛtya kanyā ādaḥ brahma loka bhāj

analyzed: devālayam ca pratimām kārayan sarvam āpnuyāt

analyzed: dāsī daḥ tu dvijendrebhyaḥ hi apsaraḥ lokam āpnuyāt

analyzed: tasya śiśna indriyam bhūpāḥ na agniḥ dahati karhicit

analyzed: siṃhagiriḥ uvāca
translated: Lion Mountain said:

analyzed: dāsīḥ pradāya bahuśas dvijasattamebhyaḥ śrī lādi śūra nṛpatīḥ ramate psarobhiḥ

analyzed: iti vallālacarite vyāsapurāṇe dānamāhātmādikīrttanam nāma pañcadaśaḥ dhyāyaḥ
translated: Thus ends the fifteenth chapter in the Vamana Purana, describing the greatness of charity and other things.

analyzed: atha ṣoḍaśaḥ dhyāyaḥ
translated: Now, the sixteenth chapter.

analyzed: vyāsaḥ uvāca
translated: Vyasa said:

analyzed: upādhyāyaḥ pitā jyeṣṭha bhrātā ca eva mahīpatiḥ
translated: The preceptor, father, elder brother, king,

analyzed: mātulaḥ śvaśuraḥ trātā mātāmaha pitāmahau

analyzed: bandhuḥ jyeṣṭhaḥ pitṛvyaḥ ca puṃsi ete guravaḥ smṛtāḥ

analyzed: mātā mātāmahī ca eva pitṛ mātṛṣvasā ādayaḥ

analyzed: śvaśrūḥ pitāmahī jyeṣṭhā dhātrī ca guravaḥ striyaḥ
translated: the mother-in-law, paternal grandmother, elder nurse, and other women are the gurus for women.

analyzed: iti uktaḥ guru vargaḥ yam mātṛtaḥ pitṛtaḥ nṛpāḥ
translated: Thus, O kings, this group of gurus is mentioned from the mother's and father's sides.

analyzed: anuvarttanam eteṣām manaḥ vāc kāya karmmabhiḥ

analyzed: gurum dṛṣṭvā samuttiṣṭhet abhivādya kṛtāñjaliḥ

analyzed: na etaiḥ upaviśet sārddham vivadet na ātma kāraṇāt

analyzed: jīvita artham api dveṣāt gurubhiḥ nā eva bhāṣaṇam

analyzed: guṇaiḥ anyaiḥ patati adhas

analyzed: gurūṇām ca eva sarvveṣām pūjyāḥ pañca prayatnataḥ

analyzed: teṣām ādyāḥ trayaḥ śreṣṭhāḥ teṣu mātā garīyasī
translated: Among them, the first three are the best, and among them, the mother is the most important.

original: yo bhāvayati yā sūte yena vidyopadiśyate /
analyzed: yaḥ bhāvayati yā sūte yena vidyā upadiśyate

analyzed: jyeṣṭha bhrātā ca bharttā ca pañca ete guravaḥ smṛtāḥ
translated: The elder brother and the husband - these five are remembered as Gurus.

analyzed: ātmanaḥ sarvva yatnena prāṇatyāgena vā punar
translated: By all means, even at the cost of one's life,

analyzed: pūjanīyāḥ viśeṣeṇa pañca ete bhūtim icchatā

analyzed: na asti pitṛ samaḥ devaḥ na asti mātṛ samaḥ guruḥ

analyzed: tayoḥ nityam priyam kuryyāt karmmaṇā manasā girā

analyzed: na tābhyām ananujñātaḥ dharmmam anyam samāśrayet

analyzed: guruḥ agniḥ dvijātīnām varṇānām brāhmaṇaḥ guruḥ

analyzed: patiḥ ekaḥ guruḥ strīṇām sarvvatra abhyāgataḥ guruḥ

analyzed: brāhmaṇam praṇamet yaḥ tu viṣṇu buddhyā nara uttamaḥ

analyzed: āyuḥ putraḥ ca kīrttiḥ ca sampattiḥ tasya varddhate

analyzed: viprāḥ hi kṣatriya ātmānaḥ na avajñeyāḥ kadācana

analyzed: dharmma śāstra ratha ārūḍhāḥ veda khaḍga dharāḥ dvijāḥ

analyzed: iti vallālacarite vyāsapurāṇe guruvargakīrttanam nāma ṣoḍaśaḥ dhyāyaḥ

translated: Salutations to the lord of the paths, to the one born of the harvest, to the radiant one.

analyzed: sūtriṇe hari keśāya puṣṭānām pataye namaḥ  vabhluśāya namaḥ vyādhine nnānām pataye namaḥ
translated: To the one with a garland, to Harikeśa, to the lord of the nourished, salutations.🔽Salutations to the one with a reddish-brown body, to the one with a disease, to the lord of foods, salutations.

original: bhavasya hetyai jagatām pataye ca namo namaḥ // / / //
analyzed: bhavasya hetyai jagatām pataye ca namaḥ namaḥ
translated: Salutations to the dart of Bhava, to the lord of the moving world, salutations, salutations.

analyzed: rudrāya ātatāyine ca kṣetrāṇām pataye namaḥ
translated: Salutations to Rudra, to the one who stretches out, to the lord of the fields, salutations.

analyzed: namaḥ astu ahantre sūtāya vanānām pataye namaḥ
translated: Salutations to the one who kills, to the one who is born, salutations to the lord of the forests, salutations.

analyzed: rohitāya sthapataye vṛkṣāṇampataye namaḥ
translated: Salutations to the red one, to the architect, to the lord of the trees, salutations.

original: bhuvantaye namastasmai varivasyakṛtāya ca // / / //🔽mantriṇe vai vāṇijāya kakṣāṇāmpataye namaḥ /
analyzed: bhuvantaye namaḥ tasmai varivasya kṛtāya ca  mantriṇe vai vāṇijāya kakṣāṇāmpataye namaḥ
translated: Salutations to the one who moves, to the one who grants favor, salutations.🔽Salutations to the one who chants mantras, to the one who trades, to the lord of the shoulders, salutations.

analyzed: ghoṣāya uccais krandayate pattīnām pataye namaḥ
translated: Salutations to the one who shouts loudly, to the one who cries out, to the lord of the foot soldiers, salutations.

analyzed: dhāvate kṛtsna vītāya sattvānām pataye namaḥ
translated: Salutations to the one who runs, to the one who covers everything, to the lord of beings, salutations.

original: namo 'stu sahamānāya namo nivyādhine namaḥ // / / //🔽āvyādhinīnāmpataye kakubhāya niṣaṅgiṇe /🔽nicerave namastubhyaṃ stenānāmpataye namaḥ // / / //🔽namo 'raṇyānāmpataye namaḥ paricarāya ca /
analyzed: namaḥ stu sahamānāya namaḥ nivyādhine namaḥ  āvyādhinīnām pataye kakubhāya niṣaṅgiṇe  nicerave namaḥ tubhyam stenānām pataye namaḥ  namaḥ raṇyānām pataye namaḥ paricarāya ca
translated: Salutations to the one who conquers, salutations to the one who pierces, salutations.🔽Salutations to the lord of the piercing ones, to Kakubha, to the one with a quiver.🔽Salutations to you, the one who moves below, salutations to the lord of thieves, salutations.🔽Salutations to the lord of the forests, salutations to the one who attends,

analyzed: stāyūnām pataye tubhyam vañcate parivañcate
translated: salutations to you, the lord of the birds, to the one who deceives, to the one who deceives all around, salutations.

analyzed: praṇamāmi iṣudhimate namaḥ tubhyam niṣaṅgiṇe
translated: I bow to the one with a bow, salutations to you, the archer.

original: taskarāṇānte pataye namāmi ca punaḥ punaḥ // / / //
analyzed: taskarāṇām ante pataye namāmi ca punar punar
translated: I bow again and again to the lord of thieves.

analyzed: sṛkāyibhyaḥ jighāṃsadbhyaḥ muṣṇatāmpataye namaḥ
translated: Salutations to the lord of those with spears, those who wish to kill, and those who steal.

analyzed: asimadbhyaḥ vikṛntānām pataye te namaḥ namaḥ
translated: Salutations again and again to you, the lord of those with swords and those who mutilate.

original: naktañcarebhyo rudrebhyo dhāvadbhyaśca namonamaḥ /🔽uṣṇīṣiṇe kuluñcānāmpataye te namonamaḥ // / / // 🔽dhanvāyibhya iṣumadbhyo namo giricarāya te /
analyzed: naktañcarebhyaḥ rudrebhyaḥ dhāvadbhyaḥ ca namaḥ namaḥ  uṣṇīṣiṇe kuluñcānām pataye te namaḥ namaḥ  dhanvāyibhyaḥ iṣumadbhyaḥ namaḥ giri carāya te
translated: Salutations again and again to the Rudras who roam at night and run.🔽Salutations again and again to you, the lord of those who wear turbans and pluck out hair.🔽Salutations to you, the mountain dweller, to those with bows and arrows.

original: ātanvābhyo vaśca pratidadhānebhyo namonamaḥ // / / //🔽āyacchadbhyo namo 'syadbhyo visṛjadbhyo namo namaḥ /
analyzed: ātanvābhyaḥ vaḥ ca pratidadhānebhyaḥ namaḥ namaḥ  āyacchadbhyaḥ namaḥ syadbhyaḥ visṛjadbhyaḥ namaḥ namaḥ
translated: Salutations again and again to those who draw and release arrows.🔽Salutations to those who draw, those who shoot, and those who release, again and again.

original: vidhyadbhyaśca svapadbhyaśca jāgradbhyaśca namonamaḥ // / / //🔽śayānebhya āsīnebhyastiṣṭhadbhyo vo namo namaḥ /
analyzed: vidhyadbhyaḥ ca svapadbhyaḥ ca jāgradbhyaḥ ca namaḥ namaḥ  śayānebhyaḥ āsīnebhyaḥ tiṣṭhadbhyaḥ vaḥ namaḥ namaḥ
translated: Salutations again and again to those who pierce, those who sleep, and those who are awake.🔽Salutations again and again to those who lie down, those who sit, and those who stand.

original: namaḥ sabhāpatibhyo vaḥ sabhābhyaśca namonamaḥ // / / //🔽aśvebhyo 'śvapatibhyaścāvyādhinībhyo namonamaḥ /
analyzed: namaḥ sabhā patibhyaḥ vaḥ sabhābhyaḥ ca namaḥ namaḥ  aśvebhyaḥ śva patibhyaḥ ca avyādhinībhyaḥ namaḥ namaḥ
translated: Salutations to you, the lords of assemblies, and again and again to the assemblies.🔽Salutations again and again to the horses, the lords of horses, and to those who are not sick.

analyzed: vividhyantībhyaḥ ca namaḥ ugaṇābhyaḥ namaḥ namaḥ
translated: Salutations to those who pierce and to the Uganas, again and again.

original: tṛṃhatībhyo gaṇebhyaśca vrātebhyaśca namonamaḥ /🔽namo gaṇapativrātapatibhyaśca namonamaḥ // / / //
analyzed: tṛṃhatībhyaḥ gaṇebhyaḥ ca vrātebhyaḥ ca namaḥ namaḥ  namaḥ gaṇapati vrāta patibhyaḥ ca namaḥ namaḥ
translated: Salutations again and again to the groups that are eager, and to the troops.🔽Salutations again and again to the lords of the groups of Gaṇas.

analyzed: gṛtsa patibhyaḥ gṛtsebhyaḥ virūpebhyaḥ namaḥ namaḥ
translated: Salutations again and again to the lords of the Gṛtsas, to the Gṛtsas, to the deformed ones.

analyzed: viśvarūpebhyaḥ ca namaḥ senābhyaḥ ca namaḥ namaḥ
translated: Salutations to those of universal form, and salutations again and again to the armies.

analyzed: senā nībhyaḥ rathibhyaḥ vaḥ a rathebhyaḥ namaḥ namaḥ
translated: Salutations again and again to you, the generals, the charioteers, and the non-charioteers.

original: kṣattṛbhyaḥ saṃgrahītṛbhyo mahadbhyaśca namonamaḥ // / / //🔽arbhakebhyastakṣakebhyo rathakṛdbhyo namonamaḥ /
analyzed: kṣattṛbhyaḥ saṃgrahītṛbhyaḥ mahadbhyaḥ ca namaḥ namaḥ  arbhakebhyaḥ takṣakebhyaḥ rathakṛdbhyaḥ namaḥ namaḥ
translated: Salutations again and again to the Kshatriyas, the commanders, and the great ones.🔽Salutations again and again to the young, the carpenters, and the chariot-makers.

analyzed: karmmārebhyaḥ kulālebhyaḥ niṣādebhyaḥ namaḥ namaḥ
translated: Salutations again and again to the blacksmiths, the potters, and the Niṣādas.

analyzed: puñjiṣṭhebhyaḥ śvanibhyaḥ ca mṛgayubhyaḥ ca vaḥ namaḥ
translated: Salutations to you, the Puñjijṣṭhas, the dog-like ones, and the hunters.

original: śvabhyaśca śvapatibhyaśca rudrāya ca bhavāya ca // / / //
analyzed: śvabhyaḥ ca śva patibhyaḥ ca rudrāya ca bhavāya ca
translated: Salutations to the dogs, the lords of the dogs, to Rudra, and to Bhava.

analyzed: nīlagrīvāya sarvvāya paśūnām pataye namaḥ
translated: Salutations to the blue-throated one, to the all-pervading one, to the lord of the animals.

analyzed: namaḥ te śitikaṇṭhāya namaḥ teḥ tu kaparddine
translated: Salutations to you, O sharp-throated one, salutations be to you, O matted-haired one.

analyzed: sahasrākṣāya ca vyapta keśāya śatadhanvane
translated: To the thousand-eyed one, to the one with scattered hair, to the hundred-bowed one,

analyzed: giriśāya namaḥ tubhyam śipiviṣṭāya te namaḥ
translated: Salutations to you, O lord of the mountains, salutations to you, O Śipiviṣṭa.

analyzed: mīḍhuṣṭamāya iṣumate hrasvāya vāmanāya ca
translated: To the most bountiful, to the wise, to the short, to the dwarf,

original: vṛhate ca varṣīyase vṛddhāya savṛdhe namaḥ // / / //
analyzed: vṛhate ca varṣīyase vṛddhāya savṛdhe namaḥ
translated: To the great, to the oldest, to the aged, to the prosperous, homage!

analyzed: prathamāya namaḥ grāyaḥ āśave ca ajirāya ca
translated: Homage to the first, to the foremost, to the swift, to the slow,

analyzed: namaḥ śīghrāya śībhyāya ūrmmāya avasvanāya ca
translated: Homage to the quick, to the speedy, to the swift, to the impetuous!

original: nādeyāya namastubhyaṃ dvīpyāya ca namonamaḥ /🔽jyeṣṭhāya ca kaniṣṭhāya pūrvvajāya namonamaḥ // / / //
analyzed: nādeyāya namaḥ tubhyam dvīpyāya ca namaḥ namaḥ  jyeṣṭhāya ca kaniṣṭhāya pūrvvajāya namaḥ namaḥ
translated: Homage to thee, O Nādāya, and homage, homage to Dvīpaya!🔽Homage, homage to the eldest, to the youngest, to the first-born!

original: madhyamāyāpagalbhāya vudhnyāyāparajāya ca /🔽jaghanyāya ca somyāya pratisaryyāya te namaḥ // / / //
analyzed: madhyamāya apagalbhāya vudhnyāya aparajāya ca  jaghanyāya ca somyāya pratisaryyāya te namaḥ
translated: Homage to the middle one, to the bold, to the river-born, to the youngest,🔽Homage to the lowest, to the Soma-worthy, to the returning one!

original: namo yāmyāya kṣemyāya ślokyāya ca namonamaḥ /
analyzed: namaḥ yāmyāya kṣemyāya ślokyāya ca namaḥ namaḥ
translated: Homage, homage to the southern, to the prosperous, to the famous, homage, homage!

analyzed: urvaryyāya avasānyāya khalyāya ca namaḥ tu te
translated: Homage to thee, O Urvarya, to the end-maker, to the ploughman!

original: namo vandyāya kakṣyāya śravāya ca namonamaḥ /
analyzed: namaḥ vandyāya kakṣyāya śravāya ca namaḥ namaḥ
translated: Homage to the venerable, to the strong, to the famous, homage, homage!

original: pratiśravāya ca namaḥ āśuṣeṇāya te namaḥ // / / //
analyzed: pratiśravāya ca namaḥ āśuṣeṇāya te namaḥ
translated: Homage to the reverberating, homage to thee, O thou of swift chariot, homage!

original: āśurathāya ca namaḥ śūrāya cāvabhedine /🔽vilmine ca kavacine varmmiṇe ca varūthine // / / //
analyzed: āśu rathāya ca namaḥ śūrāya ca avabhedine  vilmine ca kavacine varmmiṇe ca varūthine
translated: Homage to the chariot-borne, to the hero, to the breaker-through,🔽To the wielder of the thunderbolt, to the wielder of the shield, to the wielder of the armour, to the wielder of the rampart!

analyzed: śrutāya śruta senāya dundubhyāya namaḥ namaḥ
translated: Homage, homage to the famous, to the army of the famous, to the drum, homage!

analyzed: ahanyāya dhṛṣṇave ca pramṛṣāya namaḥ namaḥ
translated: To the one who should be killed, to the one who is patient, to the one who is forgiving, salutations again and again.

analyzed: tīkṣṇa ūṣave ca āyudhine su āyudhāya su dhanvane
translated: To the one with sharp arrows, to the one with weapons, to the one with good weapons, to the one with a good bow,

original: namaḥ satyāya pathyāya kāṭyāya ca namonamaḥ // / / //🔽nīpyāya ca namastubhyaṃ kulyāya ca namonamaḥ /🔽sarasyāya nādeyāya vaiśantāya namonamaḥ // / / //
analyzed: namaḥ satyāya pathyāya kāṭyāya ca namaḥ namaḥ  nīpyāya ca namaḥ tubhyam kulyāya ca namaḥ namaḥ  sarasyāya nādeyāya vaiśantāya namaḥ namaḥ
translated: Salutations to the true one, to the one on the right path, to the one on the path, salutations again and again.🔽Salutations to you, the one who flows in canals, to the one who flows in ditches, salutations again and again.🔽Salutations to the one in lakes, to the one in rivers, to the one in the rainy season, salutations again and again.🔽Salutations to the one in wells, to the one in ponds, to the one in the sky, salutations again and again.

original: avaṭyāya ca kupyāya vīghrāya ca namonamaḥ /🔽ātapyāya ca medhyāya vidyutyāya namonamaḥ // / / // 🔽avarṣyāya ca varṣāya vātyāya ca namonamaḥ /
analyzed: avaṭyāya ca kupyāya vīghrāya ca namaḥ namaḥ  ātapyāya ca medhyāya vidyutyāya namaḥ namaḥ  avarṣyāya ca varṣāya vātyāya ca namaḥ namaḥ
translated: Salutations to the one in the sun, to the one who is pure, to the one in lightning, salutations again and again.🔽Salutations to the one who does not rain, to the one who rains, to the one in the wind, salutations again and again.

original: namo brātyāya reṣmāya vāstavyāya namonamaḥ // / / //🔽vāstupāya ca somāya rudrāya ca namonamaḥ /
analyzed: namaḥ brātyāya reṣmāya vāstavyāya namaḥ namaḥ  vāstupāya ca somāya rudrāya ca namaḥ namaḥ
translated: Salutations to the one who is like a brother, to the one who is like a friend, to the one who is like a house, salutations again and again.🔽Salutations to the one who is like a house, to the one who is like Soma, to the one who is like Rudra, salutations again and again.

original: aruṇāya ca tāmrāya śaṅgave ca namonamaḥ // / / //
analyzed: aruṇāya ca tāmrāya śaṅgave ca namaḥ namaḥ
translated: Salutations to the one who is like the dawn, to the one who is like copper, to the one who is like the sun, salutations again and again.

analyzed: namaḥ ugrāya bhīmāya agrevadhāya namaḥ u stu te
translated: Salutations to the fierce one, to the terrible one, to the one who kills in front, salutations to you.

original: dūrevadhāya hantre ca namo hanīyase namaḥ // / / //
analyzed: dūrevadhāya hantre ca namaḥ hanīyase namaḥ
translated: Salutations to the one who kills from a distance, to the killer, to the one who should be killed, salutations again and again.

analyzed: sambhavāya śaṅkarāya mayobhavāya te namaḥ
translated: Salutations to the one who is born, to the one who is auspicious, to the one who brings well-being, salutations to you.

original: mayaskarāya ca śivatarāya ca śivāya ca // / / //
analyzed: mayaskarāya ca śivatarāya ca śivāya ca
translated: Salutations to the one who brings happiness, to the one who is more auspicious, to the one who is auspicious, again and again.

original: avāryyāya ca pāryyāya namaḥ prataraṇāya ca /🔽uttaraṇāya tīryyāya kubjāya ca namonamaḥ // / / //🔽namaḥ śaṣyāya pheṇyāya sikatyāya namonamaḥ /
analyzed: avāryyāya ca pāryyāya namaḥ prataraṇāya ca  uttaraṇāya tīryyāya kubjāya ca namaḥ namaḥ  namaḥ śaṣyāya pheṇyāya sikatyāya namaḥ namaḥ
translated: Salutations to the one who is not to be obstructed and to the one who is to be obstructed, to the one who rescues and to the one who delivers.🔽Salutations again and again to the one who is bent.🔽Salutations to the one who is born from the hair, to the one born from the foam, to the one born from the river-bed, salutations again and again.

original: pravāhyāya kiṃśilāya kṣayaṇāya namonamaḥ // / / //🔽iriṇyāya prapathyāya namastubhyaṃ pulastaye /
analyzed: pravāhyāya kiṃśilāya kṣayaṇāya namaḥ namaḥ  iriṇyāya prapathyāya namaḥ tubhyam pulastaye
translated: Salutations to the one who flows, to the one who is like a stone, to the one who is destroyed, salutations again and again.🔽Salutations to the one who is on the path, to the one who is on the way, salutations to you, O Pulastya.

original: namo vrajyāya goṣṭhāya talpāya ca namonamaḥ // / / //
analyzed: namaḥ vrajyāya goṣṭhāya talpāya ca namaḥ namaḥ
translated: Salutations to the one who goes, to the cow-pen, to the bed, salutations again and again.

original: gehyāya ca hṛdayyāya niveṣyāya ca te namaḥ /🔽gahvareṣṭhāya śuṣkāya harityāya namonamaḥ // / / //
analyzed: gehyāya ca hṛdayyāya niveṣyāya ca te namaḥ  gahvareṣṭhāya śuṣkāya harityāya namaḥ namaḥ
translated: Salutations to the one who is in the house, to the one in the heart, to the one who is settled, salutations to you.🔽Salutations to the one who dwells in the cave, to the one who is dry, to the one who is green, salutations again and again.

original: pāṃsavyāya rajasyāya lopyāya ca namo 'stu te /
analyzed: pāṃsavyāya rajasyāya lopyāya ca namaḥ stu te
translated: Salutations to you, to the one who is in the dust, to the one in the dirt, to the one who is lost.

original: ulapyāya ca ūrvvāya sarvvāya ca namonamaḥ // / / //🔽parṇaśadāya parṇāya namaścābhighnate namaḥ /🔽nama udguramāṇāya namaḥ ākhidate namaḥ // / / //
analyzed: ulapyāya ca ūrvvāya sarvvāya ca namaḥ namaḥ  parṇa śadāya parṇāya namaḥ ca abhighnate namaḥ  namaḥ udguramāṇāya namaḥ ākhidate namaḥ
translated: Salutations to the one who is in the grass, to the one in the thigh, to the all, salutations again and again.🔽Salutations to the one who cuts the leaves, to the one who is the leaf, salutations to the one who strikes, salutations.🔽Salutations to the one who roars, salutations to the one who bites, salutations.

analyzed: iṣu kṛdbhaḥ dhanuṣ kṛdbhyaḥ namaḥ prakhidate namaḥ
translated: Salutations to the makers of arrows, to the makers of bows, salutations to the one who strikes, salutations.

analyzed: kirikebhyaḥ ca devānām hṛdayebhyaḥ namaḥ namaḥ
translated: Salutations again and again to the Kirīka gods and to the hearts of the gods.

analyzed: vicinvatkebhyaḥ vaḥ vikṣiṇatkebhyaḥ ca namaḥ namaḥ
translated: Salutations again and again to the ones who search and the ones who scatter.

original: ānirhatebhyo yuṣmabhyaṃ namāmi ca punaḥ punaḥ // / / //
analyzed: ā nirhatebhyaḥ yuṣmabhyam namāmi ca punar punar
translated: I bow to you again and again, you who are not defeated.

analyzed: bho andhasaspate drāpe daridra nīlalohita
translated: O Lord of the blind, O Drape, O poor, O blue-red,

analyzed: prajānām naḥ paśūnām ca mā abheḥ mā arok kathaṃcana
translated: Never let Mara harm our offspring and cattle in any way.

analyzed: imāḥ naḥ rudrāya matīḥ tavase prabharāmahe
translated: We offer these thoughts to Rudra, to your powerful one,

original: grāme viśve yathā śaṃsvādvipade ca catuṣpade // / / //
analyzed: grāme viśve yathā śaṃsva a dvipade ca catuṣpade
translated: So that all may be well with our villages, with our bipeds and quadrupeds.

analyzed: yā te rudra śiva tanūḥ śiva viśvāha bheṣajī
translated: O Rudra, your auspicious form, auspicious to all beings, which is healing,

original: rudrasya bheṣajī rudra tayā no mṛḍ jīvase // / / //
analyzed: rudrasya bheṣajī rudra tayā naḥ mṛṣ jīvase
translated: O Rudra, by that healing of Rudra, be gracious to us for life.

original: rudrasya hetiḥ parito vṛṇakta tveṣasya cāsmāsu na durmmatiśca /
analyzed: rudrasya hetiḥ paritas vṛṇakta tveṣasya ca asmāsu na durmmatiḥ ca
translated: The weapon of Rudra, the terrible one, may surround you, and evil thought may not be in us.

original: sthirāṇi rudra avatāraya tvam tokāya pautrāya sukhaṃ yathā syāt // / / //
analyzed: sthirāṇi rudra avatāraya tvam tokāya pautrāya sukham yathā syāt
translated: O Rudra, you make firm the bones, so that there may be happiness for the child and the grandchild.

original: mīḍhuṣṭama śivatama śivo naḥ sumanā bhava /
analyzed: mīḍhuṣṭama śivatama śivaḥ naḥ su manāḥ bhava
translated: O most bountiful one, most auspicious one, be auspicious and well-disposed to us.

original: nidhāya parame vṛkṣe āyudhaṃ tava śaṅkara // / / //
analyzed: nidhāya parame vṛkṣe āyudham tava śaṅkara
translated: O Shankara, having placed your weapon on the highest tree,

original: kṛttiṃ vasāna āgaccha pinākaṃ dhārayan śivaḥ /
analyzed: kṛttim vasānaḥ āgaccha pinākam dhārayan śivaḥ
translated: Come, wearing the skin, holding the Pinaka, auspicious.

analyzed: namaḥ tubhyam bhagavate vikiridra vilohita
translated: Salutations to you, O Lord, O red-brown, O red-brown one.

analyzed: yāḥ hetayaḥ sahasra ante smat anyam nivapantu tāḥ
translated: Let those weapons of yours, which are a thousand, fall on another than us.

analyzed: yāḥ tava hetayaḥ vāhvoḥ sahasrāṇi sahasraśas
translated: Those thousands of arrows that are in your arms,

analyzed: tāsām īśānaḥ bhagavan parācīnā mukhākṛdhi
translated: O Lord, turn their tips away from us.

original: asaṃkhyātāḥ sahasrāṇi ye rudrā adhi bhūtale // / / //
analyzed: asaṃkhyātāḥ sahasrāṇi ye rudrāḥ adhi bhū tale
